newsitem.title: FRANCE: French court bans disputed child curfew in towns.
newsitem.headline: French court bans disputed child curfew in towns.

text.p: France's highest administrative court, the Council of State, said on Thursday it had suspended controversial midnight curfews for children in two towns.

The Council of State said it had suspended the curfews, which applied to children aged 12 and below, in the northern Paris suburb of Aulnay-sous-Bois and in Dreux, about 55 km west of Paris, pending court rulings on their legality.
It had already suspended a similar restriction in a third municipality, the southern town of Sorgues, in July.
It was unclear when the courts would deliver a decision.

The curfews, established by municipal decrees, had sparked heated debate between France's Socialist-led government, which argued that they infringed personal liberties, and right-wing mayors, who said they were needed to protect children and prevent vandalism during school holidays.
An opinion poll last month found 81 percent of French people favoured child curfews.
